content:
I'd like to share another approach to try to find anti-implications, unsuccessful until now, with which I have been toying around these days:
Let us work over the complex numbers. The linear-magmas product, xy=ax+by, is not able to prove that Astérix does not imply Obélix, because the left product map for this product is injective (when b\neq 0). The idea is then to get more "combinatorial space" while maintaining linearity, by introducing conjugated variables and studying the *-linear products
xy := ax + by + cx^* + dy^*, which are non-injective when either d=b or d=-b (b=d=0 is a degenerate case).
In spite of these products giving more parameters to play with, I have shown (by solving the resulting system of *-equations) that no complex *-linear magma is Astérix but not Obélix. For me this has been a bit surprising, does anyone see any easy reason why this may happen?

I have also tried to find a complex non-injective *-linear product for Equation 63, but again there are none. (Btw, I propose the names Dupont and Dupond, after Tintin's characters, for Equations 63 and 1692, if you like the names!) .

Anyway, perhaps this approach can work for other yet unknown pairs of identities? We can also try with other (noncommutative) rings with involution.

If anyone wants to see the proof, I have it in .tex and can upload it anywhere. :smile:

The linear and *-linear maps belong to a noncommutative ring. Unfortunately for the specific Asterix -> Oberlix construction, we know that no noncommutative linear map can furnish a counterexample (see @Pace Nielsen 's Oct 7 comment from https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/458659-Equational/topic/Equation.2065.20-.3E.20left.20cancellability ). But there could well be other unresolved implications where this method is fruitful; I would particularly focus on cases where the hypothesis only involves two variables (so that the resulting equations have a good chance of being a determined system; I assume all the hypotheses involving just one variable have been sorted out already).

Jose Brox said:

For me this has been a bit surprising, does anyone see any easy reason why this may happen?

If you replace every complex variable with a+bia+bia+bi for a,ba,ba,b real variables then your product is a polynomial map (from four variables to two variables) and the Astérix and Obélix equations become systems of polynomial equations in the coefficients. But any system of polynomial equations, some which must be satisfied and some which must not be satisfied, that admits real solutions, also admits solutions over a finite field. This shows without calculation that if this method worked it would give a finite magma which we know is impossible.

Thanks, I chose the complex numbers for ease of explanation here, but my proof actually works over any integral domain with involution (maybe we could generalize it to the noncommutative setting and to rings with nontrivial zero divisors, I haven't tried yet). So a structural explanation should also work, for example, for the free associative commutative ring with involution.

Terence Tao ha dicho:

Unfortunately for the specific Asterix -> Oberlix construction, we know that no noncommutative linear map can furnish a counterexample (see Pace Nielsen 's Oct 7 comment from https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/458659-Equational/topic/Equation.2065.20-.3E.20left.20cancellability ).

Actually, the idea of including the involution is precisely to circumvent this problem; in the cited comment of Pace Nielsen (if I found the right one!) it is just proven for linear products (actually, affine), but *-linear products are not actually linear (I meant to say that they are still of degree one) and involve more parameters, giving a different, more complex set of parametric equations in 4 parameters (involving involutions). Notice that, over (noncommutative) domains, we can just dismiss affine products without even applying the Astérix equation, just by imposing non-injectivity (since ax+by+c = ax+by' + c implies b(y-y')=0), but there are *-linear products which are non-injective over integral domains with involution (but no Astérix ones!).

If one uses "Wirtinger coordinates" and identifies a complex number z with the vector (z, z^*) in C^2, then multiplication by a now becomes multiplication by the 2 x 2 matrix diag(a, a^*), and complex conjugation becomes a reflection matrix. The complex magma with the *-linear law then becomes some subquotient or something of the magma of 2 x 2 matrices with a noncommutative linear law. So I believe for the purposes of discovering anti-implications at least, the *-linear model has the same limitations as the noncommutative linear models.

Terence Tao ha dicho:

If one uses "Wirtinger coordinates" and identifies a complex number z with the vector (z, z^*) in C^2, then multiplication by a now becomes multiplication by the 2 x 2 matrix diag(a, a^*), and complex conjugation becomes a reflection matrix. The complex magma with the *-linear law then becomes some subquotient or something of the magma of 2 x 2 matrices with a noncommutative linear law.

Ah, what a nice idea! But in order to realize conjugation (i.e., swap the diagonal elements) it is not enough to multiply (only) on the left by some matrix, we need to apply the inner automorphism given by J:=[0,1;1,0], so the *-linear product translates to
aX+bY+cJXJ + dJYJ,
where a,b,c,d are diagonal matrices representing elements of the original ring and X,Y can be general 2x2 matrices if we want. Hence we cannot factor out at the left to get something of the form
AX+BY
with A,B some 2x2 matrices, which is what we need in order to apply the linear result in the matrix ring.

The matrices here are not acting on other matrices; they are acting on vectors. However, if a law holds for the vector model, it also holds for the matrix model, and vice versa, so for the purposes of determining implications between laws, the situation is equivalent to the matrix law.

Let's take a concrete example: the law z ◇ (z ◇ w) = w ◇ z with the magma z ◇ w = az + bw + cz^* + dw^*. Writing Z = vec(z,z^*) and W = vec(w,w^*), and also A = diag(a,a^*), etc., the operation in these new coordinates is Z ◇ W = AZ + BW + CJZ + DJW (note we are performing both matrix x matrix multiplication here and matrix x vector multiplication, but they associate with each other so I dispense with parentheses). The law in question then becomes

AZ + B(AZ+BW+CJZ+DJW) + CJZ + DJ(AZ+BW+CJZ+DJW) = AW+BZ+CJW+DJZ

This has to hold for all Z, W, in a space that generates all of C^2 as a C-vector space, so we can equate coefficients and conclude that

A + BA + BCJ + CJ + DJA + CJ = B + DJ; BB + BDJ + DJB + DJ = A + CJ. (*)

Now, let us switch to a new magma, the magma of 2 x 2 complex matrices with law M ◇ N = AM + BN + CJM + DJN. This is a law with exactly the same algebraic behavior as the previous Wirtinger magma, so if the above matrix identity (*) holds, then this new matrix magma will also obey the same law M ◇ (M ◇ N) = N ◇ M as the Wirtinger magma.

But this new magma is an example of a noncommutative linear magma M ◇ N = a M + b N in a noncommutative ring, in this case the ring of 2 x 2 complex matrices, with a = A + CJ and b = B + DJ. So if we already know that such noncommutative linear magmas do not generate the anti-implications that we want, then neither will the *-linear magma.
